repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Closes #37174.

Currently only has the filters `enabled` and `filetype`. If anyone has suggestions about other useful filters, let me know and I'll add them.

Also indirectly improves `:lsp enable/disable` completion by discarding invalid configs from completion.

close #37277

comment_data.body:
In this form this would put the burden of evaluating lazy/async config properties like `root_dir` to the user of `get_configs`.

In other issues it was discussed that there should probably be some kind of `get_config(name, on_config)` function. It would trigger the `on_config` callback with the fully resolved configuration. See e.g. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33577#issuecomment-3568292351

Imho we should go into that direction.

Evaluating lazy configs was a potential problem I considered as I was implementing this, but after testing with the entirety of nvim-lspconfig, the speed is fast enough that I cannot notice it. A warning should probably be added to this function (`Note: this will eagerly evaluate all configs`). The unfortunate truth is that there is no way to search filetypes without evaluating configs.

As an alternative, if you feel that eagerly evaluating all configs is unacceptable, I think that exposing the local `get_config_names()` added by this PR (to be used with `lsp.config[...]` and a future `lsp.get_config(...)`) would be the way to go.

Edit: Updated the documentation for `get_configs()` to warn about this behavior.
I opened #37237 as an alternative to this PR, which solves this eager loading problem while introducing some limitations. imo I still like `get_configs()`.

> Evaluating lazy configs was a potential problem I considered as I was implementing this, but after testing with the entirety of nvim-lspconfig, the speed is fast enough that I cannot notice it.

It's not the performance of loading the configs I'm worried about, but about properties that can be asynchronous. Currently that's only `root_dir` but there was talk about making the full `config` a function with callback.

Then the `get_configs` interface likely wouldn't work. We'd need a callback, unless we opt for uv lib style and made a zero-arg version that's evaluating everything synchronous. But even then I'm not sure how well that would works with some of the use-cases. E.g. afaik for rust a use-case for the `root_dir` function was to spawn cargo.

Not sure what's the best direction here. But it would be strange to end up with a `get_config` that has a callback parameter for fully evaluated configurations and a `get_configs` that returns partially evaluated configurations.

Would be interesting to see what @justinmk and @lewis6991 have to say.

I'm not sure why we need to add this at all (#37174 shows no concrete use case), and I think adding this is a mistake.

LSP configs are dynamic by design, so whenever you call this you are only ever getting a snapshot, depending on the use case this may have a significant impact.
Seems that #37277 is a better way to go then?

> Seems that #37277 is a better way to go then?

That just means consumers will use that and then eager-load all the configs anyway.

Taking a step back, I do lean towards this more general approach of modifying LSP configurations via a VSCode-friendly-approach since `.vscode/settings.json` allow for keys to be prefixed by a language identifier.

comment_regular_data.body:
> But it would be strange to end up with a `get_config` that has a callback parameter for fully evaluated configurations and a `get_configs` that returns partially evaluated configurations.

That's true. And that's a hint that we should focus on `get_config` instead of rushing this other thing.

I think the discussion of `get_config` is mostly settled and waiting on implementation. It could take an optional filter and return multiple configs.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(lsp): add `vim.lsp.get_configs()`
